  â€¢ The main subject is a U-shaped tube containing a hydraulic fluid, with two pistons inserted at each end.

Summary : This is a labeled illustration of a hydraulic fluid system, showing two connected cylinders of different cross-sectional areas and pistons, used to demonstrate the principles of hydraulic pressure and force transmission.

illustration:
# System Overview :
  â€¢ Two vertical cylinders are connected at the base, forming a U-shaped container filled with hydraulic fluid.
  â€¢ The left cylinder has a larger cross-sectional area (A) and piston, while the right cylinder has a smaller area (a) and piston.
  â€¢ The left piston is labeled with an upward force F, and the right piston is labeled with a downward force f.

# Labels & Annotations :
  â€¢ The left piston is labeled "A" (area) and "F" (force).
  â€¢ The right piston is labeled "a" (area) and "f" (force).

  â€¢ The pistons are shown in cross-section, with the fluid visible beneath them.

Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a large piston is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston, resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Hydraulic System Overview :
  â€¢ Two vertical cylinders are connected at the base by a U-shaped tube filled with liquid.
  â€¢ The left cylinder is larger, labeled with piston area "A" and force "F" applied downward.
  â€¢ The right cylinder is smaller, labeled with piston area "a" and force "f" applied downward.
  â€¢ Both pistons are shown pressing down on the liquid, with the liquid level equal in both arms.

Labels & Notation :
  â€¢ Left piston: "A" (area), "F" (force).
  â€¢ Right piston: "a" (area), "f" (force).
  â€¢ Dashed horizontal line indicates equal liquid level.
  â€¢ Persian text at the bottom: "Ø´Ú©Ù„ Û²" (Figure 2).

Spatial Relationships :
  â€¢ The larger piston (left) and smaller piston (right) are at the same liquid height, indicating pressure transmission.
  â€¢ The U-shaped tube ensures the fluid connects both pistons.

Analysis :
  â€¢ The figure visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  â€¢ The system demonstrates how a small force on a large area (F on A) can be converted to a different force on a small area (f on a), or vice versa, depending on the area ratio.
  â€¢ The equal liquid levels indicate equilibrium, supporting the concept that F/A = f/a. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.062,t=0.472,r=0.278,b=0.611), with ID d63acc51-0aaf-4841-82f9-992da7abf615 -->

Summary : This figure compares the pressure relationships in hydraulic systems with pistons at different levels, illustrating the effect of height difference on pressure transmission and the corresponding equations.

illustration:
# Left Panel: Pistons at Different Levels (Piston 2 Higher)
  â€¢ Shows a U-shaped tube with two pistons: piston 1 (area a, force f) at a lower level, piston 2 (area A, force F) at a higher level (height difference h).
  â€¢ The pressure at both pistons is set equal: Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The equation shown: f/a = F/A + Ïgh, where Ï is fluid density and g is gravitational acceleration.

# Middle Panel: Pistons at Different Levels (Piston 2 Lower)
  â€¢ Similar U-tube, but piston 2 is now at a lower level than piston 1 (height difference h).
  â€¢ The pressure equality: Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The equation: f/a + Ïgh = F/A.

# Right Panel: Pistons at the Same Level
  â€¢ U-tube with both pistons at the same horizontal level.
  â€¢ Pressure equality: Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The equation: f/a = F/A.

# Headings and Labels:
  â€¢ Top left and middle: "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†" ("The pistons at different levels").
  â€¢ Top right: "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ØªÙ€ÙˆÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙŠ" ("The pistons at the same horizontal level").
  â€¢ Each panel is labeled with variables (a, A, f, F, h, Ï, g) and the relevant equations.

# Analysis :
  â€¢ The figure demonstrates that when pistons are at different heights, the pressure transmission between them is affected by the hydrostatic pressure difference (Ïgh), which must be added or subtracted depending on which piston is higher.
  â€¢ When pistons are at the same level, the pressure relationship simplifies to a direct ratio of forces to areas (f/a = F/A), as in Pascal's principle.
  â€¢ The equations visually reinforce the importance of height differences in hydraulic systems. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.108,t=0.651,r=0.888,b=0.892), with ID 3a6e153f-a4e4-4aeb-9e61-daeaf26f4834 -->
